content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: basic problem, maybe a bit easy with the formula but suited for fastest&shortest

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Le jeu est simple à réaliser et est un très bon exercice pour apprendre aux nouveaux développeurs à réaliser des conversions entre types dans les langages typés. Il perd cependant de l'intérêt dans les langages non typés

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it is a good starting problem

I'm really surprised there is so much controversy over a temperature conversion question. I thought temperature conversion was something that people learned early on, but maybe we only do it in the US because we like Fahrenheit so much. Either way, in over 300 challenges I've never come into contact with a temperature conversion challenge so I thought this would be a fun and original challenge that I have yet to see and it would take less than 5 minutes to complete. Honestly, after the time I've spent on this contribution and the responses I've gotten I'm almost done with contributing at all. I thought Clash contributions should be short problems with clear explanations that could be solved in under 5 minutes. I didn't realize there was so much subjectivity in the originality of a problem. After the amount of duplicated, unoriginal, and down right simple (like multiply two numbers together, simple) clashes that I've faced, I'm surprised to get this kind of response to a problem that is not just a simple multiply or convert to binary problem like so many out there. "Not an original idea, Sorry!" Is not the way you grow contributors in your community.
i think it's too easy if we have the formula, and to do it in reverse may be i think hard. I don't know i'm indecisive on this one

Not a very original idea. It's just a variant of hello world for pocket calculators.
Sorry!
0 < b, t constraint is still wrong.

Updated description to include formula for temperature conversion. I still think this can be done in reverse easier than a lot of the reverse puzzles I've come into contact with, but I'm fine with it not being reverse.

I can see that reverse is not available anymore. That’s good. 

The flaw with your argument « people can see it’s a linear function » is that actually one should be able to write code from the specifications, not the tests !
Said differently, I think a problem can be valid only if one can solve it by reading the description, writing code and start it. Reverse-engineering test cases should not be an option (unless you are in reverse mode). 

Why don’t you just add the formula in the description ?
I cannot see the point not doing it.

Hey how can I tell who edited things and what they changed? I assumed it would be customary to explain why an edit was made to help improve future contributions, but it looks like things were changed and it's hard to track what all was changed. Also some of the edits are incorrect; the constraint 0 < b, t is not accurate.
Not sure how this is supposed to be done in reverse?
Please see updates, sorry WIP was my first time playing around with contributions. Let me know if any of this is off.
Sorry just playing around with how contributions work here, I have a better plan for this one, will update soon.
I don't like the idea that the solution requires a specific knowledge about how to change from one temperature to another. It has nothing to do with programming at all.
p gets.to_i*9/5+32

Tests and validators should not be the same

Also I think there should be more test cases
is the idea to golf a solution or present a solution here that is easy for viewers to undertand?
This would be pretty simple to solve with no knowledge of temperates just recognizing that the inputs and outputs are the x and y in a linear equation.

The higher or lower in the test cases makes it obvious that we are comparing the numbers. After that, you find the same cases and its pretty easy to solve even if you don't immediately recognize things like 32 and 0 being the same and know temp conversions.
I agree it should be customary. Maybe we should force a message udate
updated

What is your originality threshold for clash of code exactly? And what level of work do you require to be more than "hello world for pocket caluclators." This takes N numbers, does calculations, and outputs three different options of text. I really don't think that's "Hello world"
LOL everyone asked to add the formula acting like it was too hard without it.

Also...   

"Contributions must be original. (for all games but Clash of Code)"

Hello Injustice, I'm sorry you have had a bad experience with the contribution system.
The guidelines have changed several times last year. A lot of moderators still expect Clash of Code to be original even if it doesn't have to be. I think also that some of them find simple exercises not original because they don't have fun solving them and expect to encounter more challenging exercises. This is not an excuse but an explanation.
We have thought of adding a difficulty tag in the puzzle, and also perhaps leagues but nothing is planned yet.
Thank you for contributing to CodinGame

This is not about me ("what is your…", "what do you require"), I am trying to help you get less down and more up votes.
A Clash of Code worth playing should try to present a problem that the players have not seen before. 
Good luck!

Originality is not requisite for Clash of Code. Please check the contribution guidelines:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/contribution-guidelines

What is the point of that? Why would I (the solver) assume it is a linear relation? I know it is s WIP but it needs serious update. And most importantly tests and validators MUST differ, don't forget it for the real one.
